name: NPR
text:
A national group of evangelical doctors is asking churches to halt in-person services, saying Christians who gather now "don't care that we may be contributing to others getting this illness because of our selfishness."
https://t.co/otpwix2uTu

name: NPR
text:
President Trump ordered no more than 15,000 refugees be admitted to the U.S. in 2021 — the lowest level in the history of the modern refugee program. President-elect Biden promises to raise that number to 125,000.
https://t.co/lUga2o1epW

name: NPR
text: NPR's Scott Simon remembers historian and travel writer Jan Morris, who died Friday at age 94.   https://t.co/5KOc2XRuJq

name: NPR
text:
After a meeting with President Trump, just days away from Michigan's election certification deadline, state lawmakers defended their election process — saying it should be "free from threats and intimidation."
https://t.co/YbaAb6v3JL

name: NPR
text:
A report on an inquiry into Australia's special forces in Afghanistan recommends 19 soldiers be referred to criminal investigation for killing 39 Afghans in 23 separate incidents.

Now, the U.S., U.K. and others face calls to conduct similar probes.

https://t.co/6JMX6FnBPJ

name: NPR
text: A federal judge in Pennsylvania ruled that the campaign's claims were "unsupported by evidence" and essentially asked the court "to disenfranchise almost seven million voters." https://t.co/50iYU7zQU2

name: NPR
text:
China's restrictions targeting spiritual and educational life for Muslims are intensifying. Mosque demolitions have spread. Islamic scholars, writers, religious leaders and their families are under constant state surveillance.
https://t.co/zl0ohfqIGX

name: NPR
text: After 30 years in prison, and five years on stringent parole, former U.S. Navy analyst Jonathan Pollard plans to move to Israel, his lawyers said. https://t.co/TRdejUFiRG

name: NPR
text: Saudi Arabia, which is hosting this year's virtual G-20 summit, opened up the two-day meeting urging leaders to mount a global response to the coronavirus pandemic. https://t.co/OQvhop0BSE

name: NPR
text:
Vermont's Republican governor has embraced COVID-19 safety measures. South Dakota's Republican governor has loudly opposed them.

Their infection rates:
◾  Vermont — about 500 cases per 100,000 people
◾ South Dakota — about 8,000 cases per 100,000 people
https://t.co/1i9vHy7ZyP

name: NPR
text: Whether it means making a tiny turkey, writing Thanksgiving letters, or staying in PJs and ordering takeout, "the way that we can support each other is by not being together," a small business owner says. https://t.co/jhD3OBV4fM

name: NPR
text:
"Animaniacs 2.0" feels bogged down by its overwhelming need to speak to our Trumpian era, writes @craftingmystyle — and Yakko, Wakko, and Dot face the conundrum of how to parody a culture that's become a parody of itself. 
https://t.co/a1vg3cKaEa

name: NPR
text:
Several big farm groups — traditionally hostile to environmental regulations — are now working with climate advocates in support of farmer-friendly actions to reduce carbon emissions.
https://t.co/wJy7CNbH7k

name: NPR
text:
New York Gov. Andrew Cuomo will receive the International Emmy Founders Award for his "use of television to inform and calm people around the world" during his daily coronavirus briefings earlier this year.
https://t.co/09PSasyuvi

name: NPR
text:
Sarah Paulson starred in "American Horror Story" and "American Crime Story," so @waitwait invited her to play a game called "Canadian Horror Story" — 3 questions about terrible things that have happened in Canada.
https://t.co/tSGHNfBJh7
